Name: Principles
Author: Ray Dalio
Recap:
When you experience pain, remember to reflect. You can convert the “pain” of seeing your mistakes and weaknesses into pleasure: you have found an opportunity to get better;⭐️⭐️;Finished;💰 Economy;
The Slight Edge;Jeff Olson;https://m.media-amazon.com/images/I/41PZ3XJQT+L.jpg;July 19, 2020;Small actions compound over time. The things you do every day, the things that don’t look like they matter, do matter. They not only make a difference—they make all the difference.

Name: How to Win Friends and Influence People
Author: Dale Carnegie
Recap: Always give others the impression that you are important. A bit cynical, but very interesting

Name: Machine Learning with Python
Author: Sebastian Raschka
Recap: Pure gold: loong book with tons of formulas and code, but very interesting stuff with a 360 degree view of the basics of ML. I feel very prepared now and will look back on it in the future!

Name: Smarter Faster Better
Author: Charles Duhigg
Recap: Productivity is about recognizing choices that other people often overlook. Productivity emerges when people push themselves to think differently!

Name: The Intelligent Investor
Author: Benjamin Graham
Recap: Do not trust Mr. Market. Don't buy shares but the underlying business: value investing is based on noticing if there is a margin (large enough) between price and value and exploiting it. That was so wise

Name: What Every Body is Saying
Author: Joe Navarro
Recap: Our limbic system - that is, the honest system - speaks the truth. Observe the small details and changes in people carefully and interpret them with the right context. We are still animals: to danger we freeze flight or fight. One of the most important books in psychology, I enjoyed it

Name: The Way of the Peaceful Warrior
Author: Dan Millman
Recap: There are no ordinary moments! The way of the peaceful warrior is to appreciate every moment, regardless of how dull or ordinary it may seem. Live in the present. Meh, difficult to read

Name: The Richest Man In Babylon
Author: George S. Clason
Recap: Save a tenth of what you earn and let the children of your saved money have more children, and again, and again … Very basic and obvious advices, yet lightweight

Name: The 100-Year Life
Author: Lynda Gratton
Recap: I will live to be 100, statistically. My life will be much more variable than I thought, with various work stages. Be flexible about it! Open-minded about our future.

Name: Automate the boring stuff with Python
Author: Al Sweigart
Recap: With Python, you can automate any boring and predictable task. A fundamental book for my, and very fun to read

Name: A Mind for Numbers
Author: Barbara Oakley
Recap: Recall. Rework and question what you just read, simplifying it as if you were explaining it to a child. I should have read it in high school

Name: 21 Lessons for the 21st Century
Author: Yuval Noah Harari
Recap: History repeats itself. We have to study it and learn from the mistakes. Brilliant masterpiece with many, many things to think about

Name: Clean Code
Author: Robert C. Martin
Recap: The Boy Scout Rule: Leave the code better than how you found it. I will follow every page of it

Name: The Defining Decade
Author: Meg Jay
Recap: The future isn’t written in the stars. There are no guarantees. So claim your adulthood. Be intentional. Get to work. Pick your family. Do the math. Make your own certainty. Don’t be defined by what you didn’t know or didn’t do. You are deciding your life right now.

Name: An Open Heart
Author: Dalai Lama
Recap: The best response to an enemy who wants us to harm is to be happy: getting stressed is just his game, without even intervening. Boring.

Name: Guerrilla Analytic
Author: Enda Ridge
Recap: Keep the work folder organized, in a simple, predictable and intuitive way. Few things learned from there

Name: Thinking Fast and Slow
Author: Daniel Kahneman
Recap: It is not possible to explain the rationality (or rather, the lack thereof) of the human soul, which has two systems that are opposed to each other according to the foreseeable and intuitive cases. Important book, with many things explained, I'm seeing it all around mentioned in other books

Name: Antifragile: Things that Gain from Disorder
Author: Nassim Nicholas Taleb
Recap: Antifragility is beyond resilience or robustness. The resilient resists shocks and stays the same

Name: Never Split the Difference
Author: Rick Voss
Recap: Listen. Tons of cool trick for negotiating and cool stories, this was so well written

Name: Designing Data-intensive Applications
Author: Martin Kleppmann
Recap: Databases have a ton of possible problems to explore, understand and predict. Especially those distributed. Good book, but I feel a bit scared by the difficulties of that world

Name: Getting Things Done
Author: David Allen
Recap: If you can do this in less than two minutes, do it, otherwise delegate it or write it down in your super archive. Great idea, a bit paranoid though

Name: The Millionaire Fastlane
Author: MJ DeMarco
Recap: Become an entrepreneur, satisfy a need (scalable) and multiply your wealth exponentially, this is the fastlane. Meh, wannabe-millionaire stuff

Name: A Flag Worth Dying For
Author: Tim Marshall
Recap: Each flag is much more than a piece of cloth, it represents millions of people and what they believe. There are fascinating stories behind them. Lovely book that explains the story of each country in a few lines

Name: Nudge
Author: Cass R. Sunstein, Richard H. Thaler
Recap: Well-planned prods can be very effective in helping people make their choices. This is liberal paternalism. Amazing idea!

Name: Uncanny Valley
Author: Anna Wiener
Recap: The startup world is full of crap and possessed. Let's take it with ironic detachment. I love how she wrote, his style was so cynical and stinging

Name: The Seven Principles for Making Marriage Work
Author: John Gottman
Recap: The key to a happy marriage is how you approach conflict. In the strongest marriages husband and wife share a deep sense of meaning. They don’t just ‘get along’—they also support each other’s hopes and aspirations and build a sense of purpose into their lives together.

Name: The Body Keeps The Score
Author: Bessel Van der Kolk
Recap: Past traumas can seriously affect people's future. I'm doubtful about the method presented, and the stories were frightening

Name: What Color is your Parachute?
Author: Richard N. Bolles
Recap: Prepare and understand yourself, studying to find the right job for you. Boring, boring, boring. It was like a manual, old-fashioned and repetitive

Name: The 4-Hour Work Week
Author: Tim Ferriss
Recap: Delegation, 80/20. Your most important asset is time. Usual productivity stuff

Name: The Gervais Principle
Author: Venkatesh Rao
Recap: The structure is divided into Losers, Clueless and Sociopaths, each with its own rules and strategies. Weird book, I read it because I liked The Office, but I feel confused about the theory

Name: Head First Design Patterns
Author: Eric Freeman
Recap: Pattern designs are useful tools in your toolbox to use when you feel the need. I needed such an easy-going book for learning about them!

Name: Why We Sleep: Unlocking the Power of Sleep and Dreams
Author: Matthew Walker
Recap: Getting enough and regular sleep is essential to living a happy and healthy life. I will follow his advices

Name: The Millionaire Next Door
Author: Thomas J. Stanley, William D. Danko
Recap: Income and Wealth are two different things: there are those who earn a lot but do not have much and those who earn less but increase their capital with frugality. Many millionaires are of the second kind (PAW). A bit too repetitive and obvious towards the end

Name: Bullshit Jobs: A Theory
Author: David Graeber
Recap: Part of the office work is useless and creates a dangerous sense of depression for the worker. Interesting concept, I had the feeling that the second part was just a repetition

Name: A Short History of Nearly Everything
Author: Bill Bryson
Recap: We are very lucky to be here, alive, and we have only one chance and one planet to survive. Loved it, I will read the story again

Name: La Rana Bollita: una storia d'ansia
Author: Marina Immorta
Recap: Anxiety can be unbearable and it seems impossible to get out of it. The protagonist made it with a lot of patience, yoga, gymnastics and a desire to change. Absolutely brilliant, I bought the physical book

Name: Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance
Author: Robert Pirsig
Recap: Does quality permeate the universe? I don't know. Ah, often if you have patience and attention you can keep the bike without always going to a mechanic. I didn't understand this book at all, it seems overrated

Name: The Warren Buffett Way
Author: Robert G. Hagstrom
Recap: Buffett doesn't buy to speculate, but looks carefully at numbers, managers and undervalued ideas, for the long term. I  found his life rather interesting, and I understood the strategy

Name: Mythos
Author: Stephen Fry
Recap: The Greeks have many funny stories that have left us a memory even in the present, especially in the etymology of many words. Fun book with tons of strange stories, recommended

Name: The Dip
Author: Seth Godin
Recap: Be the best or withdraw. Winners know the perfect time to go out. Meh, nothing new

Name: Reckoning with Risk
Author: Gerd Gigerenzer
Recap: Learn to use the thumb rules to make simple, quick and comfortable decisions when needed. Cool one, with very convincing examples

Name: The Art Of Data Science
Author: Robert Peng
Recap: Always think about the right model for your data and don't underestimate biases. Good book, technical and with well-explained principles

Name: How to Have Impossible Conversations
Author: James A. Lindsay, Peter Boghossian
Recap: The goal is not to win, but to listen ... and perhaps instill doubt. It opened my mind about negotiating, recommended

Name: The Design of Everyday Things
Author: Donald A. Norman
Recap: Good design is invisible, it means that everything is fine. Bad design screams inadequacy and confuses users

Name: Head First HTML and CSS
Author: Elisabeth Ronson, Eric Freeman
Recap: HTML and CSS have some problems with various browsers, but they are very important for understanding how web pages work. Old-fashioned and simple, but I love the funny style

Name: Refactoring
Author: Martin Fowler
Recap: It's easy to write code that a machine understands. What's difficult is writing code that a human understands. I will follow the refactoring rules!

Name: Good Calories, Bad Calories
Author: Gary Taubes
Recap: Carbohydrates and sugars cause problems, much more than fats. Extremely long and technical

Name: Il Fascismo Eterno
Author: Umberto Eco
Recap: Fascism has some important key traits, let's not forget them. It was way shorter than I was expecting

Name: The Monk and The Riddle
Author: Randy Komisar
Recap: A startup requires passion, but also a solid plan and a willingness to work hard and understand the market. Good way to explain a point, using a dialogue like Greek philosophers

Name: Salt Sugar Fat: How the Food Giants Hooked Us
Author: Michael Moss
Recap: They may have sugars, salts and fats on their side, but we have the power to inform and choose. Bonus: I didn't know there were so many sugars in packaged desserts! I must be careful

Name: Food Rules: An Eater's Manual
Author: Michael Pollan
Recap: Eat food. Mainly vegetable. Not too much. Short and useful book about nutrition

Name: The Swerve: How the World Became Modern
Author: Stephen Greenblatt
Recap: Lucretius influenced the whole world with De Reris Naturam and finding his manuscript was a fascinating adventure. Honestly I didn't fully understood why it was so important, but the story is well written

Name: The Book of Awesome
Author: Neil Pasricha
Recap: Life is AWESOME. Enjoy the moments, the little moments of joy that happen to you. Almost annoyting with toxic positivity, yet I had fun with all those little moments of AWESOME

Name: Hands-on Machine Learning with Scikit-Learn and TensorFlow
Author: Aurélien Géron

Name: Applied Statistics and Probability for Engineers
Author: DC Montgomery

Name: So Good They Can't Ignore You
Author: Cal Newport

Name: Extreme Ownership: How U.S. Navy SEALs Lead and Win
Author: Jocko Willink

Name: Bogleheads' Guide To Investing
Author: Mel Lindauer, Michael LeBoeuf, Taylor Larimore
Recap: Tune Out The Noise - Master Your Emotions. Long, technical book

Name: The Simple Path to Wealth
Author: J.L. Collins
Recap: Spend less than you earn - invest the surplus- avoid debt. It opened my eyes about personal finance

Name: Your Money or Your Life
Author: Monique Tilford, Joseph R. Dominguez, Vicki Robin
Recap: Nine Magical Steps to Create a New Road Map. Solid method, very precise

Name: The Subtle Art of Not Giving a F*ck
Author: Mark Manson
Recap: Suffering Guide: Accept it, and beat yourself up just for your fight. Do not try. Cynical and well-written

Name: The Power of Habit
Author: Charles Duhigg
Recap: Signal -> Routine -> Gratification. We are constantly guided by habits, learn to recognize it. Very useful!

Name: Emotional First Aid
Author: Guy Winch
Recap: Rejection, Loneliness, Loss, Guilt, Rumination, Failure, and Low Self-esteem: quick recipes to heal these invisible (but painful) wounds. Extremely useful!

Name: The Accounting Game
Author: Judith Orloff, Darrell Mullis
Recap: On a daily basis, cash runs the business. Not profit. I loved the writing style, it was like a children's book

Name: A Brief History Of Time
Author: Stephen Hawkins
Recap: With a complete theory we will explain why the universe exists, we will decree the triumph of human reason: since then we would know the mind of God.. Not an easy one, but wow.

Name: Your Money and Your Brain
Author: Jason Zweig
Recap: Think Twice. Our brains are full of bias, don't get caught up in the moment. THINK.

Name: How to Stop Time
Author: Matt Haig
Recap: Everything will happen for the best. Or at least it will happen: so there is no point in worrying. I understand that the way to stop time is to stop being dominated by it. Excellent start, then it gets boring towards the end

Name: Digital Dementia
Author: Manfred Spitzer
Recap: The media are evil, they make us stupid and fat More than anything else, don't make children abuse them. I don't like how the author writes

Name: Foundation
Author: Isaac Asimov
Recap: The Foundation's History is ... Complicated. 1200 pages of great sci-fi

Name: The 4 Pillars of Investing
Author: William J. Bernstein
Recap: Invest early, a lot, in ETF / Index Fund with a balanced mix, as you will NEVER know the future. Solid reading, maybe one of the best in the field
